headline.main: Navigation Institute Plans 2-Day Meeting at Academy

results.abstract: NASA plans to convert spent stage of Saturn rocket into manned orbiting lab by having astronauts separate from rocket in orbit, turn Apollo craft around and link up with airlock device on rocket; airlock would be 15-ft-long, 5 1/2-ft-diameter double-hatch chamber to permit astronauts to crawl from craft to rocket; plan will make orbiting lab possible in '68 instead of '69 as planned previously; NASA negotiating $9-million contract with McDonnell Co to design airlock; NASA denies it is trying to steal march on USAF MOL project, gives USAF engineers permission to use flight for experiments to study astronauts' ability to live and work in prolonged weightlessness; diagrams show craft linked to rocket and airlock device

headline.main: Saturn Rocket May Be First U.S. Manned Orbiting Laboratory; Use of a Spent Stage May Permit NASA to Speed Project

results.snippet: United States space engineers have conceived an ingenious plan that could make it possible  to fly the nation's first manned orbiting laboratory at least a year earlier than had been expected in 1968 instead of 1969.
results.lead_paragraph: United States space engineers have conceived an ingenious plan that could make it possible to fly the nation's first manned orbiting laboratory at least a year earlier than had been expected in 1968 instead of 1969.

headline.main: SPACE SCIENTISTS TO OPEN CONGRESS; 1,000 Gather in Madrid for World Astronautical Talks

results.snippet: MADRID, Oct. 9 Space scientists of the world gathered here today to begin the weeklong 17th International Astronautical Congress, an annual review of the technical progress man is making in his quest to reach beyond his own planet.
results.lead_paragraph: MADRID, Oct. 9 Space scientists of the world gathered here today to begin the weeklong 17th International Astronautical Congress, an annual review of the technical progress man is making in his quest to reach beyond his own planet.

results.abstract: NASA says 1st manned Apollo and 1st lunar landing will carry TV cameras to provide natl networks with live pictures from space; sees such use becoming routine in future

headline.main: Apollo to Send Back Live TV From Space; APOLLO TO SEND LIVE TV PICTURES

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that the first manned Apollo spacecraft would be equipped with a television camera capable of providing the national networks with live pictures from space.
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that the first manned Apollo spacecraft would be equipped with a television camera capable of providing the national networks with live pictures from space.

headline.main: U.S. Plans to Hurdle Obstacles To Space 'Walks' by Astronauts; 7 Hours of Experience

results.snippet: MADRID, Oct. 11--Future astronauts, if they are to work effectively outside their capsules, must have more streamlined suits, better self-propulsion systems and anchoring devices to hold them to their work sites like steeplejacks, American space...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: MADRID, Oct. 11--Future astronauts, if they are to work effectively outside their capsules, must have more streamlined suits, better self-propulsion systems and anchoring devices to hold them to their work sites like steeplejacks, American space officials said today.

results.abstract: Stafford gives to US Merchant Marine Acad 2 small acad flags he carried in memory of late Comdr See; See had hoped to carry flags to moon with him

headline.main: KINGS POINT IS GIVEN FLAGS BY ASTRONAUT

results.snippet: KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 13 (UPI)--Astronaut Thomas P. Stafford presented two small Kings Point flags today to the United States Merchant Marine academy on Long Island, flags that were to have flown to the moon with Comdr. Elliot M. See.
results.lead_paragraph: KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 13 (UPI)--Astronaut Thomas P. Stafford presented two small Kings Point flags today to the United States Merchant Marine academy on Long Island, flags that were to have flown to the moon with Comdr. Elliot M. See.

results.abstract: USAF launched 2 secret satellites last summer to study phenomenon of 'cold welding'; vacuum in space causes oxide films on metals to evaporate and radiation cleans surfaces, making metals susceptible to joining; satellites are 8-sided and covered with solar cells, have poppet valves and small metal hemispheres, which are repeatedly opened and closed, to study bonding problem; Dr J M Denny proposed design; co builds 29 such satellites for USAF and NASA

headline.main: SATELLITES TEST SPACE 'WELDING'; Bonding of Metal Surfaces in Cold a Major Problem

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 "Cold welding," a phenomenon that has cost millions of dollars in rocket and satellite failures, is quietly being investigated by two satellites launched secretly last summer.

byline.original: By EVERT CLARK Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 "Cold welding," a phenomenon that has cost millions of dollars in rocket and satellite failures, is quietly being investigated by two satellites launched secretly last summer.

results.abstract: Tass repts USSR seeks astronauts 40-50 yrs old; says 'functional abilities,' not age, are of 'decisive importance'; Dr Yegorov notes certain psychoses develop before 30, others after 50; Dr Flickinger (US) skeptical

headline.main: SOVIET LIFTS AGE FOR ASTRONAUTS; Experienced Scientists Up to 50 Are Being Sought

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Soviet Union is seeking scientistastronauts 40 to 50 years old who have "a wealth of experience," according to Tass, the official press agency.
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Soviet Union is seeking scientistastronauts 40 to 50 years old who have "a wealth of experience," according to Tass, the official press agency.
